SENT.plain: The Gasperini syndrome is a very rare brainstem disease characterized by the typical combination of ipsilateral lesions of the cranial nerves V-VII and dissociated contralateral hemihypesthesia, whereas both contralateral and ipsilateral hypacusis was described
Since the first description in 1912, only a few cases of this crossed brainstem syndrome were published so far
Pontine infarction and bleedings were the reported causes of the syndrome
Here we report a 44-year-old man with the classical Gasperini syndrome due to pontine demyelination in multiple sclerosis
The clinical findings were correlated with changes on MRI

The present case shows that classical crossed brainstem syndromes are topological terms not invariably associated with brainstem ischemia in particular vascular areas and may contribute to the differential diagnosis of peripheral facial nerve palsy
